<s>Ex. 34. Nitrous Acid injured the colours more than water, but 
they were still visible. 
Ex. 35. Olive Oil introduced between the lenses, rendered the 
colours invisible; but when the flat side of a Rose Diamond 
was substituted for one of the lenses, the colours reappeared; 
& in every other case, when Diamond was substituted for glass, 
the colours were improved therby. 
Ex. 36. When coloured fragments of the abovementioned glass 
globes were immersed in the different fluids, the results were 
conformable to the 33, 34, & 35 experiments. in water the 
colours were not much injured; in Nitrous Acid they were 
little more than perceptible; & in Olive Oil they disappeared. 
If a table is formed of the above mentioned fluids, in the order 
of their refractive powers, beginning with the greatest, & ending with 
the least, it will at the same time serve also to express the order 
of the intensity of the prismatic colours, as seen in the foregoing 
experiments, beginning with the faintest, & ending with the most 
intense, thus. 
Order of the intensity of colour
1 Olive Oil 4
2 Nitrous Acid 3
3 Water. 2
4 Air. 1
5 Vacuo. 0
order of refractive power
On a retrospective review of the foregoing results, it will be 
observed that there is one striking circumstance common to all 
the experiments where prismatic phenomena have been 
produced, either between flat surfaces or lenses, or have appeared 
in thin plates; namely, that the efficient surfaces must be 
within extremely small indefinite distances from each other; 
that within those limits whether the experiments are made 
in Air or Vacuo the colours never fail to appear: but 
beyond them they never have been seen: an Obvious con-
clusion follows, viz. that whatever is the cause of the 
phenomena; its operation is confined within these limits. 
It was admitted by Sir Isaac Newton that "reflection, refraction 
& inflection of the rays of light were all performed by one & 
the same principle acting variously in various circumstances 
& that mutual action & reaction between  bodies & light take place 
at some indefinitly small distances from the surfaces
